item.title: Connect 4 Gym
item.description: My goal is to completely solve the game of Connect4 (also sometimes called Four in a row). By completely, I mean completely. Essentially, I am going to go through all the steps in making a fully functional connect 4 robot that can play a physical game, and yes that includes building a robotic arm, a vision system, a learning algorithm that will enable our agent to learn to play from scratch, and everything else in between that is needed to tie it all together.

item.title: Conway's Game of Life
item.description: First in a series of mini-projects. The famous game of life originally conceived by the late John Conway is a fascinating example of a [Cellular Automaton][https://mathworld.wolfram.com/CellularAutomaton.html] (of which there are many). The game of life is often given as a homework task to undergraduate students in introductory programming courses – if this is you I encourage you to look deeper into the motivation behind the conception of the game of life, or simply Life.

item.title: Siamese Networks
item.description: Recently I have been looking into Siamese networks in my research, for my own understanding I like to implement new models that I come across - if you can code it you must understand it! Lets begin. What is a Siamese Network? There are some great resources on the web that answer this question, in particular this short course by distinguished researcher Andrew Ng. For completeness I will explain the idea briefly here.

item.title: Tutorial: Multi-threading and tkinter
item.description: On occasion in my work I need a visualisation that gives a bit more than what pyplot can provide. tkinter was an obvious choice as a fairly powerful pure python GUI library it has (almost) everything one might need for simple interactive interfaces. As always, and with little to no understanding of the library I jumped straight in and tried to develop a super complicated GUI for a project I have been working on called vacuumworld.
